719458f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - Mulberry Street
719458f-a.text:
East Houston Street, west from Mulberry Street. The buildings shown
on the south side of the street, west from Lafayette Street (where horse-
drawn wagon is seen) were later razed to make way for the construction
of the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway).
September 19, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
719458f-a.folder: Houston Street (East) & Mulberry Street, Manhattan, NY

721820f-b.title: Manhattan: Mulberry Street - Houston Street (East)
721820f-b.text:
Mhilberry Street, north from and including East Houston, to
and including Bleecker Streeta..
March 13, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
The same, from a different angle, but not including Bleecker
Street. Also shown is East Houston Street, north side, east from
and including Mulberry Street, to and including the Bowery. The vie
shows part of buildings razed for the Eighth Ave., Municipal Subway.
The building with the flag is the old New York Police Headcuarters.
March 13, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
721820f-b.folder: Mulberry Street & Houston Street (East), Manhattan, NY

719460f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - Mulberry Street.
719460f-a.text:
East HEouston Street, at the S. W. corner of Mulberry
Street, showing the Puck statue perched upon the Puck
Building, a structure occupying the entire block.
About 1929
Berenice Abbott, phoko
NO REPRODUCTIONS
719460f-a.folder: Houston Street (East) & Mulberry Street., Manhattan, NY

719457f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - Mulberry Street
719457f-a.text:
39 East Houston Street, south side, west from Mulberry (left), to
Lafayette (right) Streets, showing the Puck Building, erected sometime
between the 2nd and 3rd quarters of the 19th Century. This structure
occupies the block bounded by East Houston to Jersey Streets, and
Mulberry to Lafayette Streets. It is an edifice in the Italian Renaissance
style and is occupied by the J. Ottman Lithographing Co., foremost establish-
ment of its kind on the American continent and the publishers of the
maganine ''Puck,'' a periodical, satirising political and social groups.
The clearance, shown in the foreground was caused by demolitions on the
north side of East Houston Street, during the construction of the Eighth
Ave. Subway. Also shown, on the left, is an extensive view southward on
Mulberry Street.
June 3, 1933.
719457f-a.folder: Houston Street (East) & Mulberry Street, Manhattan, NY

721819f-a.title: Manhattan: Mulberry Street - Houston Street (East)
721819f-a.text:
300 Mulberry Street, adjoining the N.E. corner of East Houston Street.
This structure shown is the old New York Police Headquarters; the
inscription across same being, Central Department of the Metropolitan Police.
About 1910.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
721819f-a.folder: Mulberry Street & Houston Street (East), Manhattan, NY

719459f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - Mulberry Street
719459f-a.text:
East Houston Street, north side, east from Mulberry Street, showing
construction work in progress on the IIndependent System Subway (Eighth
Ave. subway) after demolition of the houses which formerly stood there.
December 21, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
719459f-a.folder: Houston Street (East) & Mulberry Street, Manhattan, NY
